extendedIngredients.name: jalapeno
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2-4 roasted hatch chiles, or one fresh jalapeño, stemmed

extendedIngredients.name: yellow onion
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 medium yellow onion, peeled and quartered

recipes.title: How to Make Hatch Chile Salsa Verde

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Noir, Riesling, and Sparkling rosé are great choices for Salsa Verde. Acidic white wines like riesling or low-tannin reds like pinot noir can work well with Mexican dishes. Sparkling rosé is a safe pairing too. You could try J Vineyards & Winery Pinot Noir. Reviewers quite like it with a 5 out of 5 star rating and a price of about 48 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: J Vineyards & Winery Pinot Noir
productMatches.description: At J, we are devoted to the concept of terroir in the Russian River Valley, and our 2013 J Vineyards Pinot Noir is a reflection of this vintage, the vineyards and our attention to detail in the winery. Delivering bright berry flavors-red cherry, raspberry and blackberry- this elegant Pinot is enhanced by notes of licorice and red tea, which linger on the finish. Aromas of wild strawberries and spices delight the nose.

recipes.instructions: Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F. Spray a baking sheet with cooking spray and place the tomatillos, quartered onion and garlic cloves on the baking tray. If using a jalapeo, add it to the baking tray with the other vegetables. Roast the vegetables for 20 minutes flipping the vegetables at the 10 minute mark. The tomatillos should be lightly charred and the onion beginning to brown. Transfer the roasted vegetables and roasted Hatch chiles (or jalapeo) and any remaining juice on the baking sheet to a food processor or blender. Blend until almost smooth. Add the cilantro leaves and kosher salt and pulse a few more times until mixed. Serve the salsa topped with cotija cheese if desired and yellow or white corn tortilla chips for dipping.

steps.step: Preheat the oven to 450 degrees F. Spray a baking sheet with cooking spray and place the tomatillos, quartered onion and garlic cloves on the baking tray. If using a jalapeo, add it to the baking tray with the other vegetables. Roast the vegetables for 20 minutes flipping the vegetables at the 10 minute mark. The tomatillos should be lightly charred and the onion beginning to brown.
Transfer the roasted vegetables and roasted Hatch chiles (or jalapeo) and any remaining juice on the baking sheet to a food processor or blender. Blend until almost smooth.
Add the cilantro leaves and kosher salt and pulse a few more times until mixed.
Serve the salsa topped with cotija cheese if desired and yellow or white corn tortilla chips for dipping.
